results.name: Agardite-(Y)
results.occurrence: Oxidation zone of copper veins or deposits
results.otheroccurrence: In the oxidation zone of some copper deposits.
results.aboutname: Named by Jacques E. Dietrich, Marcel Orliac, and François Permingeat in 1969 for Jules Agard (November 21, 1916 Grenoble, France - February, 2003), geologist with the Bureau de Recherches Géologiques et Minières, Orléans, France.
results.morphology: Crystals are acicular hexagonal prisms, elongated along <mi>[0001]</mi>, a few mm long, may be stepped or hollow tubes; in radiating fibrous aggregates.

results.name: Agardite-(Ce)
results.tlform: Acicular crystals up to 0.5 mm long and 0.01 mm thick. commonly in radiating aggregates.
results.occurrence: Secondary, oxidation zone.
results.aboutname: Named by Kurt Walenta and Thomas Theye in 2003 for its relationship to the other Agardite series species.
results.type_specimen_store: Institut für Mineralogie und Kristallchemie, Stuttgart, Germany (holotype).

results.name: Agardite-(La)
results.occurrence: Fluorite mine
results.otheroccurrence: In small amounts in the oxidised zone of hydrothermal mineralised breccia and polymetallic mineral deposits (Red Cloud mines, New Mexico, USA).
results.colour: Grass-green to dull green, yellowish green to intense bluish green, rarely nearly colourless.
results.aboutname: Named by Peter J. Modreski in 1983 for its relationship to the other agardite series minerals, and for the predominance of lanthanum as the predominant REE.
results.morphology: Crystals acicular, prismatic, to 3 mm, in tufted groups, spherical rosettes.
results.type_specimen_store:
Mineralogical State Collection "Reich der Kristalle", Munich, Germany, numbers MSM 22482, MSM 22497 (type).
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, numbers 148987, 148988 (cotype).

results.name: Akdalaite
results.mindat_formula_note: Formerly given as 5Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><sup>.</sup>H<sub>2</sub>O.
results.tlform: lenslike aggregates and tabular to equant hexagonal crystals to 0.1 mm
results.occurrence: veinlets cutting amesite-fluorite-muscovite rock and fluorite-magnetite-diopside-vesuvianite skarn
results.colour: White, pale greenish yellow in thin section
results.aboutname: For the Kazakh name, Akdala, for the type locality.
results.morphology: As hexagonal crystals, to 0.8 mm, tabular to equant; in lenslike aggregates.
results.type_specimen_store: A. E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia
results.commentcrystal: Possible space groups: P6<sub>1</sub>22, P6<sub>1</sub>

results.name: Astrocyanite-(Ce)
results.tlform: Delicate rostettes of tablets.
results.occurrence: Oxidation product of uraninite.
results.aboutname: From the Greek άστρον ("astron") for "star", κυανός ("kyanos") for "blue", in allusion to its colour and habit of the aggregates, and the dominant lanthanide element in its composition.
results.other: Soluble with effervescence in dilute HCl.
results.morphology: Platy {001}
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: Strongly pleochroic from bright blue to pale blue, almost colorless.
results.type_specimen_store: Institut royal des Sciences naturalles de Belgique, Brussels, Belgium.
results.commentcrystal: <mi>space group P6/mmm, P6mm, P622, P_62m or P_6m2</mi>

results.name: Stichtite-2H
results.description_short: Originally named barbertonite. Recognised as a polytype of stichtite and accordingly discredited (Mills et al., 2011, 2012).
results.tlform: Platy crystals, fibrous matted masses and cross-fiber veinlets
results.occurrence: Alteration products of chromite in serpentinite
results.colour: Intense violet to rose-pink; violet to light rose-pink in transmitted light
results.aboutname: For the type locality, Barberton District, Transvaal, South Africa.
results.morphology: Platy crystals, flattened on {0001}. Massive, in matted or contorted masses of fibers or plates; also as cross-fiber veinlets.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc:
O = dark rose-pink to violet
E = light rose-pink to violet
results.type_specimen_store: Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA (No. 92549)
results.commentcrystal: Data of cotype specimen (from Mills et al., 2011); Z = 1/4.

results.name: Bastnäsite-(Ce)
results.occurrence: Narrow bands in a contact metamorphic amphibole skarn.
results.otheroccurrence: Most abundant REE mineral. Hydrothermal and primary igneous. Granitic and alkali syenites and pegmatites, carbonatites, contact metamorphic deposits, rarely in detrital deposits.
results.parting: On {0001} distinct to perfect of secondary origin).
results.colour: Yellow, reddish-brown; colourless to light yellow in transmitted light
results.aboutname: For the type locality at the Bastnäs mines, Riddarhyttan, Skinnskatteberg, Västmanland, Sweden, plus the "-(Ce)" suffix due to the dominance of cerium in the composition.
results.other:
Soluble in strong, hot acids.

May be found as pseudomorphs after Fluocerite or Tscheffkinite.
results.morphology: Crystals tabular {0001}, usually with <mi>{10_10}</mi> alone. Crystals normally deeply grooved horizontally due to oscillatory combination of <mi>{10_11}</mi> and <mi>{10_10}</mi>. Large anhedral masses; granular.
results.epitaxidescription: Bastnäsite forms oriented overgrowths and alteration pseudomorphs after fluocerite. Crystal axes of both species oriented in parallel position.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: Faintly pleochroic with absorption E is greater than O.
results.type_specimen_store: Swedish Museum of Natural History 23:0476

results.name: Bazzite
results.occurrence: Granite
results.otheroccurrence: Found in miarolitic cavities in granites, granite pegmatites and in Alpine veins associated with pegmatitic minerals.
results.colour: Deep blue or other shades of blue, blue-green.
results.aboutname: Named in 1915 for Alessandro Eugenio Bazzi (1892-1929), discoverer of the mineral.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc:
O = pale greenish yellow
E = intense sky-blue
results.ir: Water type II molecules (H–H vector perpendicular to the c-axis) are only observed in samples from Kent (Kazakhstan); H<sub>2</sub>O IId type is indicated by the bands at 1621 and 3663 cm<sup>−1</sup>, while the ones at 1633 and 3643 are indicative for th
results.type_specimen_store:
Municipal Museum of Natural History, Milan, Italy.
University of Milan, Milan, Italy.
The Natural History Museum, London, England, 1925,534.
Natural History Museum, Paris, France, 115.132.
results.commentcolor: The blue colour is caused by appreciable iron contents, and, more specifically, the ratio between <f>Fe#2#+ and Fe#3#+</f> (Taran et al., 2017).

results.name: Belkovite
results.tlform: Thin rims on barian pyrochlore and as barrel-shaped crystals up to 1.0 mm.
results.occurrence: Dolomite-calcite carbonatites.
results.aboutname: Named in honor of Igor Vladimirovich Belkov (Игорь Владимирович Белков) (13 August 1917, Tashkent, Uzbekistan - 18 November 1989, Apatity, Russia), mineralogist, Director, Kola Scientific Center, Apatity, Russia, who explored the Kola Peninsula.
results.type_specimen_store:
Mining Institute, St. Petersburg, Russia, 2036/1.
Geology Museum, Kola Branch, Academy of Sciences, Apatity, Russia, 6014.
A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, p584.

results.name: Bellbergite
results.tlform: Hexagonal dipyramidal crystals.
results.occurrence: In leucite tephrite lava at contacts between lava and calcium-rich xenoliths.
results.aboutname: Named for the <l id='204826'>Bellberg</l> (or Bellerberg) volcano, Germany, the type locality.
results.morphology: Hexagonal dipyramidal crystals.
results.type_specimen_store: University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria.
results.commentcrystal: Point Group:<mi> 6/m 2/m 2/m; _6m2; or 6mm; Space Group: P63 /mmc; P63mc; or P_62c</mi>

results.name: Benitoite
results.colour: Sapphire blue, white to colorless, pink
results.aboutname: After the type locality, "as it occurs near the head waters of the San Benito River in San Benito County", California, USA.
results.other: Cathodoluminescent
results.morphology: Flat pyramidal crystals.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc:
O= colorless
E= purple, indigo, greenish blue
results.uv:
Invariably fluorescent blue in SW UV.
Blue shortwave-excited luminescence excited by SW UV caused by titanate groups (TiO<sub>6</sub>)
results.type_specimen_store: No defined type material.

results.name: Braitschite-(Ce)
results.mindat_formula_note: Formula based on the crystal structure refinement: Ca<sub>6.15</sub>Na<sub>0.85</sub>REE<sub>2.08</sub>[B<sub>6</sub>O<sub>7</sub>(OH)<sub>3</sub>(O,OH)<sub>3</sub>]<sub>4</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O). It may thus be simplified as NaCa<sub>6</sub>(Ce,La)<sub>2</sub>[B<sub>6</sub>O<sub>7</sub>(OH)<sub>3</sub>(O,OH)<sub>3</sub>]<sub>4</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O) (Rowland et al., 2011)
results.tlform: Rounded nodules in anhydrite.  The nodules are a mixture of minerals.  The braitschite-(Ce) is minute hexagonal plates.
results.occurrence: Evaporite deposit
results.aboutname:
Named by O.B. Raup, A.J. Gude, E.J. Dwornik, F. Cuttitta, and H.J. Rose in 1968 in honor of Otto Braitsch (17 December 1921 - 25 July 1966), professor at the University of Freiburg, Germany, for his contributions to evaporite mineralogy and geochemistry.  The suffix follows IMA naming rules an indicates the dominant rare-earth element.

The name is pronounced brītsch'ite.
results.morphology: Simple hexagonal plates, having only prism and pinacoid faces.
results.type_specimen_store: U. S. National Museum, Catalog Number 120627.

results.name: Brannockite
results.tlform: Very thin hexagonal plates, to 1 mm; {0001} form dominates.
results.occurrence: Vugs and fractures of late-hydrothermal parts of a Li-Sn pegmatite.
results.aboutname: Named by John S. White Jr., J.E. Arem, J.A. Nelen, P.B. Leavens, and R.W. Thomssen in 1973 in honor of Dr. Kent Combs Brannock (20 July 1923, Independence, Virginia, USA - 21 February 1973, Kingsport, Tennesse, USA), chemist and mineral collector. He did a lot of early collecting at the type locality (Foote Mine).
results.morphology: Plates, showing {001} (dominant), {100}, {110}, and {114). The ratio of thickness to width is about 1:20.
results.twinning: common, perpendicular to [0001] (observable by X-Ray analysis only)
results.type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 125045.
results.commentcolor: semitransparent

results.name: Britholite-(Ce)
results.tlform: Brown, apparently hexagonal prisms embedded in a nepheline-syenite pegmatite matrix.
results.occurrence: Nepheline-syenite pegmatite.
results.colour: Colorless, pale pink to pink, pale blue, brown, greenish brown, yellow, resin brown, black.
results.aboutname: First found by Gustav Flink in 1897 in a nepheline-syenite pegmatite at <l id=1963>Naujakasik, Ilimaussaq complex, Greenland</l>, and provisionally named "a cappelenite-like mineral".  Described and named by Chr. Winther (1901). Named after the greek βρῖθος (brithos) for weight,  refering to the high specific gravity of the mineral. Later it was renamed as britholite-(Ce) as part of the changes in nomenclature for rare-earth minerals (Levinson 1966). The suffix "-(Ce)" refers to the dominance of cerium in the composition.
results.morphology: Forms: Hexagonal prism <mi>{10_10}</mi>, pyramid <mi>{10_11}</mi> and prism <mi>{11_20}</mi> (from type description). Prismatic crystals.
results.type_specimen_store:
University of Copenhagen, Copenhagen, Denmark.
The Natural History Museum, London, England, 85379.
results.commentcrystal: Some studied samples are monoclinic pseudo-hexagonal with spacegroup P21.

results.name: Britholite-(Y)
results.tlform: Massive, measuring about 1-2 cm in diameter. Rarely as short prismatic crystals to 3 cm. The outer part of the mineral is always altered into earthy substance of yellowish white or yellowish brown color.
results.occurrence: Granite pegmatite.
results.aboutname: First described as abukumalite by Hata (1938) from the <l id='5813'>Suishoyama pegmatite, Fukushima Prefecture, Japan</l>.  Later it was renamed as britholite-(Y) as part of the changes in nomenclature for rare-earth minerals (Levinson 1966). It is named for its relation to britholite-(Ce) and the suffix "-(Y)" due to the dominance of yttrium in the composition.
results.other:
Readily dissolved in cold dilute mineral acids.

Magnetic property is weaker than allanite and greater than yttrialite and xenotime.
results.type_specimen_store: Type material destroyed in WWII.
results.commentcolor: Yellowish-brown in thin sections.

results.name: Brockite
results.tlform: Reddish brown resinous masses.
results.occurrence: Calcite vein in granite.
results.aboutname: Named in 1962 by Frances G. Fisher and Robert Meyrowitz in honor of Maurice Rex Brock (4 March 1922 - 26 December 2004, Denver, Colorado, USA), U.S. Geological Survey, who supplied the first specimen.
results.other: Radioactive
results.type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 121952.
results.commentcrystal: Space group uncertain: P6222 (?).
results.commentcolor: Red color may be due to admixed hematite.

results.name: Bromellite
results.tlform: White hexagonal crystals
results.occurrence: In hydrothermal calcite veins and veinlets in hematite skarn and skarnized limestones
results.aboutname: For Magnus von Bromell (1679-1731), Swedish physician and mineralogist.
results.morphology: As prismatic crystals, elongated along [0001], to 1 mm, showing pyramidal hemimorphism, with <mi>{000_1} and {10_10} well developed, {10_11}</mi> small, may be tabular parallel to {0001}; in randomly intergrown rosettelike aggregates; also as cleavage fragments, to 10 cm.
results.uv: Yellowish white in both LW and SW UV
results.type_specimen_store: Swedish Museum of Natural History, Stockholm, Sweden
results.commentcrystal: synthetic

results.name: Brugnatellite
results.tlform: in lamellar or foliated masses, forming nodules, crusts, and coatings.
results.occurrence: A hydrothermal alteration product in serpentinite
results.aboutname: Named in 1909 by Ettore Artini in honor of Luigi Valentino Brugnatelli [1859-1928], Professor of Mineralogy, University of Pavia, Italy.
results.morphology: Massive. Lamellar or foliated masses of small flakes flattened {0001}. Individual flakes have a three- or six-sided outline with striations intersecting at 60°.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc:
O = yellowish red
E = colourless
results.type_specimen_store: Municipal Museum of Natural History, Milan, Italy.
results.commentcrystal: Point Group: 3 (probable).; Space Group: n.d.

results.name: Burbankite
results.tlform: Intimately intergrown with ancylite as irregular masses or veinlets, and as separate crystals in calcite.
results.occurrence: Hydrothermal deposits composed essentially of silicates, carbonates, and sulfides, cutting shonkinite.
results.otheroccurrence: accessory mineral in carbonatites
results.colour: Colorless, grayish yellow, pale yellow, pink, pale greenish.
results.aboutname: Named after Wilbur Sweet Burbank (30 March 1898, Amesbury, Massachusetts, USA – 1 April 1975), geologist with the United States Geological Survey, in recognition of his contributions to the geology of mineral deposits of the western United States.
results.other: Effervesces strongly in cold dilute (1:5) HCl.
results.morphology: Long dihexagonal prismatic crystals with shallow pyramidal terminations, striated parallel [001], may be in fibrous spherical aggregates; anhedral granular, to 5 cm.
results.type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 106843.

results.name: Burtite
results.tlform: As pseudo-octahedral crystals to 2 mm
results.occurrence: From a garnetite in a tin-bearing skarn
results.aboutname: Named after Dr. Donald McLain Burt (1943– ), Professor of Mineralogy, Arizona State University, Tempe, Arizona, USA, authority on mineral equilibria in skarn and greisen deposits, who had predicted the natural occurrence of the compound.
results.opticalcomments: Uniaxial (+); sections exhibit very weak birefringence and interference figures; typically appears isotropic. n = 1.633(1)
results.type_specimen_store: Catholic University of Louvain, Louvain, Belgium, EH80016.
results.commentluster: surface typically earthy due to alteration.
results.commentcrystal: Hexagonal, pseudocubic. Point Group:<mi> _3 (probable).; Space Group: R_3 probable, R3, R32, R3m, R_3m possible; Pn3 actually observed, thought due to twinning. </mi>

results.name: Beryl
results.impurities: Fe, Mn, Mg, Ca, Cr, Na, Li, Cs, O, H, OH, H2O, K, Rb
results.otheroccurrence: Commonly found in pegmatites. Red beryl is found in topaz rhyolites.
results.colour: Colorless, green, blue, yellow, white, pink, etc.
results.aboutname: Possibly from the Greek "beryllos" which referred to a number of blue-green stones in antiquity.
results.commentcolor:
green (Cr3+, ±V3+; emerald) to yellow (Fe2+; heliodor), light blue (Fe3+; aquamarine), sea-green (Fe2+ and Fe3+; beryl), pink (Mn2+; morganite), red (Mn3+; red beryl), colorless (goshenite), and white.
[[1]]The d–d transition of Fe3+ with six-fold coordination, the O2−→Fe3+ charge transfer, and the charge transition of binuclear metal M–M complexes formed by [Fe2(OH)4]2+ in the channel caused a yellow tone, whereas the charge transfer of Fe2+/Fe3+ with six-fold coordination caused a blue-green tone. The chroma of blue-green beryl was negatively correlated with the ratio of Cs+Mn to Fe contents. The lightness of blue-green beryl was negatively correlated with the total content of transition metal ions.

results.name: Calcioburbankite
results.tlform: Subhedral, deep orange, prismatic crystal 2 x 1.8 x 2 cm in size.
results.colour: Deep to pale orange, silky white to light pink, colorless
results.aboutname: Named in allusion to its composition wherein CALCIum substitutes for strontium in regular Burbankite.
results.other: Dissolves rapidly in 10% HCl.
results.morphology: Elongate parallel to [001], wittt {100} dominant.
results.type_specimen_store: Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, CMNMC 50804 HT specimen.
results.commentcrystal: space group may also be P63mmc or P-62c

results.name: Cacoxenite
results.otheroccurrence: Common accessory mineral in oxidation zone of magnetic and limonite iron ores, novaculites, rarely in iron rich sediments and soils.
results.colour: Yellow to brownish yellow, reddish orange, golden yellow, deep orange, green
results.aboutname: From the Greek κακός for "bad" and ξένος for "guest" due to the fact that the phosphorous content of cacoxenite lessens the quality of iron smelted from ore containing it.
results.other: Readily soluble in acids.
results.morphology: Crystals crudely hexagonal, acicular [0001], with a hexagonal cross section at times and indistinct pyramidal faces. Commonly in compact, concentric, spherical to radial aggregates. In bundles, randomly fibrous; as coatings or intergranular cement.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc:
O = Pale yellow
E = Canary yellow to yellow orange
results.type_specimen_store: No defined type material.
results.commentcolor: Yellow in transmitted light.

results.name: Cancrinite
results.mindat_formula_note: Pekov et al. (2011) propose the following idealised formula: <f>Na^7Ca[Al^6Si^6O^24](CO^3)1.5•2H^2O</f>.
results.otheroccurrence: Primary mineral in alkalic igneous rocks, alteration product of nepheline.
results.colour: grey-green, white, yellow, blue, orange, reddish
results.aboutname: For Count Egor Frantsevich Kankrin (Georg Cancrin) (16 November 1774 – 10 September 1845), Russian Minister of Finance.
results.morphology: Commonly massive, rarely as prismatic crystals.
results.commentcrystal: Range of unit-cell parameters: a = 12.58-12.76 Å, c = 5.11-5.20 Å.

results.name: Cancrisilite
results.tlform: Anhedral, granular, to 3 mm.
results.occurrence: ultra-agpaitic pegmatites in a differentiated alkalic massif.
results.aboutname: Named in allusion to the relatively high ratio of silicon to aluminumin its composition, and its relationship to cancrinite.
results.type_specimen_store: Vernadsky Geological Museum, Moscow; A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, p503/1.

results.name: Carbonate-rich Fluorapatite
results.description_short: A variety of fluorapatite with carbonate group (CO3) substituting for some of the phosphate (PO4) groups.
results.tlform: earthy to massive
results.otheroccurrence: Found in sedimentary phosphate beds, frequently in hard nodules; uncommon accessory mineral in late-stage mineralization in granite pegmatites, rarely found in polymetallic ore veins.
results.colour: White, pale gray, creamy white; frequently stained yellow, brown,  red, or black by iron oxides and other minerals
results.aboutname: Named in 1906 by Peter Nikolaevich Chirvinsky [Carbapatit] or in 1916 by Reinhard Brauns [Carbonatapatit] from the Greek word meaning "to deceive" and the CARBONATE- prefix in allusion to the presence of some carbonate substitution for phosphate. Many early synonyms exist for this mineral including pseudoapatite, francolite, collophane, dahllite, carbapatite, podolite, quercylite, kurskite, grodnolite, etc., but not all of these names represent homogeneous materials nor are strictly applied to fluorine-dominant compositions.
results.other: Soluble in HCl or in HNO3. Varieties containing CO3 may dissolve with slight effervescence.
results.commentdense: earthy varieties have a lower density

results.name: Carrboydite
results.occurrence: secondary mineral in the oxidized zone of nickel sulfide deposits
results.aboutname: Named for the Carr Boyd nickel mine, Australia, the type locality.
results.type_specimen_store:
Western Australian Museum, Perth, Australia, M.74.1991.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, 135930.
results.commentcrystal: Point Group: n.d; Space Group: n.d.

results.name: Cesanite
results.tlform: A solid vein, 1 cm thick. Also as a cavity-filling in an explosive breccia. The vein has a sugary texture and grain size ranging from 0.2 to 1.5 mm. Individual crystals, mostly subhedral and loosely packed, can be easily removed.
results.occurrence: Core sample from a geothermal well in volcanic and pyroclastic rocks.
results.aboutname: After the type locality, the Cesano No. 1 well, Cesano geothermal field, Bracciano Lake, Rome Province, Latium, Italy.
results.other:
Low solubility in water (etch-pits develop after prolonged contact with distilled water). Grains develop rounded edges in HCl and H2SO4 (both cold and hot). Hot HNO3 produces corroded edges, and a superficial film of white powdery material. Cesanite crystals are entirely dissolved in aqua regia after a short time.

Readily decomposes under an electron beam, even when stronger defocused.
results.morphology:
Short prismatic, hexagonal shaped, with a length to diameter ratio between 2:1 and 4:1. Striations on the prism faces.

Forms include the prism <mi>{10_10}</mi>, pyramid <mi>{10_11}</mi>, pinacoid {0001}, and another pyramid <mi>{10_1l}</mi>.
results.type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the Museum of Mineralogy of the University of Rome (specimen no. 24316/1). Material from the same vein has been also presented to the Naturhistorisches Museum Wien (Austria) and to the City Museum of Natural History, Milan (Italy).
results.thermalbehaviour: The DTA curve exhibits three major endothermal peaks at 425°, 605° and 740 DC, plus a shoulder at about 760-770°C.
results.commentluster: Single crystals appear greasy, aggregates appear silky.
results.commentcrystal: P-6 according to Piotrowski et al. (2002). Originally assumed to be P63/m.

results.name: Chiluite
results.tlform: Plumose replacements in joseite inclusions in bismuthinite; as veinlets and as irregular to hexagonal isolated grains isolated in bismuthinite; as a rim on koechlinite, the exterior having a hexagonal outline. Grain size generally 10-20 µm (maximum 42 µm).
results.occurrence: In quartz veins in a bismuth deposit.
results.aboutname: Named for the type locality, Chilu molybdenum deposit.
results.type_specimen_store: National Museum for Geology, Beijing, China, number M09636.
results.commentcrystal: Point Group: 622, 6/m, or 6.; Space Group: P6322, P63m, or P63.

results.name: Chlorapatite
results.tlform: White hexagonal crystals.
results.otheroccurrence: Veins in gabbroic rocks; in meteorites.
results.aboutname: Name introduced in 1860 by Carl F. Rammelsberg, in his Handbuch der Mineralchemie. Here he reviewed some analysis of apatites, and found that apatite may have fluor(F) or chloride (Cl) as the dominant anion. An analysis of apatite from Kragerø, Norway (cited after Völker) showed 4.10 wt % Cl, and was named as chlorapatite. The name is made of the prefix, chlor, for the dominant chlorine and the Greek ἀπατάω (apatao), to deceive, as apatite was often confused with other minerals (e.g. beryl, milarite). The name was changed in 2008 to apatite-(CaCl), but was quickly reverted back to chlorapatite in 2010.
results.other: Soluble in HCl or in HNO3. Varieties containing CO3 may dissolve with slight effervescence.
results.morphology: Crystals short to long hexagonal prisms [0001], with <mi>{10_10}</mi> and <mi>{10_11}</mi> dominant; also thick tabular {0001}, frequently in the crystals of hydrothermal origin in pegmatites and veins, with <mi>{10_10}</mi>, relatively large {0001}, and often also <mi>{10_11}</mi> or low pyramids. Massive, coarse granular to compact.
results.twinning: Rare contact twins on <mi>{11_21}</mi>. Twin plane <m>{10_13}</mi> rare. Also twinning reported on <mi>{10_10}</mi> and <mi>{11_23}.
results.type_specimen_store: No designated type material.
results.commentcrystal: May be monoclinic, space-group P21/m (a = 9.605, b = 19.210, c = 6.785 A, β = 120°, Z = 6)

results.name: Chlormagaluminite
results.tlform: Hexagonal dipyramids to more than 1 mm.
results.occurrence: Skarn.
results.colour: Colorless to yellow-brown; colorless in transmitted light
results.aboutname: For its composition: chloride, magnesium and aluminium.
results.morphology: Hexagonal dipyramids.
results.type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, number 82771.

results.name: Claringbullite
results.mindat_formula_note: Originally assumed to be Cu<sub>4</sub>(OH)<sub>7</sub>Cl.nH<sub>2</sub>O.
results.tlform: Slightly divergent group of blue plates up to 1 mm across on cuprite.
results.aboutname: Named in honor of Gordon Frank Claringbull (21 August 1911 - 23 November 1990), former Keeper of Mineralogy and Director of the British Natural History Museum, London, England. He helped describe six new minerals including the rare gemstones taaffeite, sinhalite, and painite.
results.morphology: Thin plates in slightly divergent groups. Crystals are flattened on {0001}.
results.type_specimen_store:
The Natural History Museum, London, England, number 1976,109 (Zambian).
University of Pierre and Marie Curie, Paris; National School of Mines, Paris, France (Katangan).
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, number 145660.
results.commentcolor: Pale blue in transmitted light.
results.ima_history: Originally approved with the formula <f>Cu^4Cl(OH)^7</f>. Redefined by IMA in 2016, as it was recognised that the correct formula of claringbullite is <f>Cu#2+#^4FCl(OH)^6</f>.

results.name: Connellite
results.tlform: Blue acicular crystals in divergent clusters, usually < 1 mm.
results.colour: Blue, blue-green; blue in transmitted light.

results.name: Fluorapatite
results.otheroccurrence: Most common rock forming phosphate. Accessory mineral in most igneous rocks with important concentrations in carbonatites. Common in marbles and skarns. Major mineral in sedimentary phosphorites.
results.colour: Colourless to white when pure, also green, blue, pink, yellow, brown, violet, purple.
results.aboutname: Renamed in 1860 from the original <m>apatite</m> of Abraham Werner by Carl F. Rammelsberg to emphasize the chemical composition. Apatite is from the Greek ἀπατάω (apatao), to deceive, as apatite was often confused with other minerals (e.g. <m>beryl</m>, <m>milarite</m>). Rammelsberg added the "Fluor-" prefix in allusion to the dominance of fluorine in the composition. See Weiss (2012) and Meier (2013) for the nomenclature history of apatite.
results.other: Soluble in HCl or in HNO3. Varieties containing CO3 may dissolve with slight effervescence.
results.morphology: Crystals short to long hexagonal prisms [0001], with <mi>{10_10}</mi> and <mi>{10_11}</mi> dominant; also thick tabular {0001}, frequently in the crystals of hydrothermal origin in pegmatites and veins, with <mi>{10_10}</mi>, relatively large {0001}, and often also <mi>{10_11}</mi> or low pyramids. Massive, coarse granular to compact.
results.twinning: Rare contact twins on <mi>{11_21}</mi>. Twin plane <mi>{10_13}</mi> rare. Also twinning reported on <mi>{10_10}</mi> and <mi>{11_23}</mi>.
results.epitaxidescription: Needle-like rutile crystals included in the apatite with the c-axes of the two species parallel; Monazite in oriented inclusions; Carbonate-fluorapatite enclosing fluorapatite.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc:
Weak to strong in coloured crystals:
Colour: .Violet .........Pale       Green .............Yellow ..............Blue
O = ..Deep violet .....Pale yellow ..Yellow-brown ......Sky-blue
E = ..Red-violet .Pale blue-green ..Dark green ...Green-blue
results.opticalcomments: Refractive index increases with diminished fluorine content.
results.uv:
Often fluorescent bright yellow or blue white and phosphorescent, especially the manganoan varieties.

The REEs-doped FAp powders synthesized by hydrothermal methods produce fluorescence of different wavelengths. Er-, Eu-, Pr-, Ho-, and Yb-doped FAps can, respectively, emit blue, orange, red, orange, red, and green light under the excitation of ultraviolet light (250 nm). Compared with the Pr/Sm/Gd/Ho/Yb-doped FAps, Er/Eu-doped FAps exhibit high fluorescence intensity, attributed to their small lattice distortion, big grain size and suitable doping concentration.[[1]]
results.commentcrystal: May be space group P21/b.

First described as a new mineral from <l id='21881'>Kopeisk, South Urals, Russia</l> by Chesnokov et al. 1987). The name was originally fluorellestadite, changed to ellestadite-(F) by the IMA in 2008, and back to fluorellestadite by the IMA in 2010.

results.name: Graphite
results.aboutname: Named "plumbago" in 1739 by Magnus von Bromell, but in a different sense than previous authors such as Agricola and Conrad Gesner. Also called "molybdaena", but "molybdaena" was shown to represent two species, <M>molybdenite</M> and <M>graphite</M> - as known today, in 1781 by Carl Wilhelm Scheele. Named graphite in 1789 by Abraham Gottlob Werner from the Greek "graphein", "to write".

results.name: Greenockite
results.otheroccurrence: An uncommon mineral of sulfide deposits.
results.aboutname: The naming of the mineral is often attributed to Henry James Brooke and Arthur Connell in 1840. The original description was actually made by Robert Jameson who first described greenockite, and the first description was in “his journal”: The Edinburgh New Philosophical Journal. The mineral was named for Lord Greenock - later Earl Charles Murray Cathcart, 2nd Earl Cathcart [December 21, 1783, Walton-on-the-Naze, Essex, England, UK - July 16, 1859, St Leonards-on-Sea, Hastings, England, UK]. Earl Charles Murray Cathcart was a general in the British army and served as Governor of the Province of Canada. He was also the author of two papers: one on igneous rocks in Edinburgh, Scotland and one on coal in southern Scotland.

The mineral was on display, by Hanks, at the 1884 World's Industrial and Cotton Centennial Exposition at New Orleans, labelled as thenardite but noted by Hidden to be something different.

A crystal of the mineral was examined by Dana and Penfield in 1883, but the source locality was unknown so they waited to publish until more was found.

Peacor, and Bozidar Darko Sturman in honor of Richard "Dick" Philip Hauck [June 30, 1935 Bloomfield, New Jersey, USA -  ] formerly of Bloomfield, New Jersey, USA, and now a resident of Franklin, NJ. Author and co-founder of the Sterling Hill Mining Museum, Ogdensburg, NJ. He is a charter member and a former President of the Franklin-Ogdensburg Mineralogical Society, the Geoliterary Society, and the Franklin Mineral Museum. He is a lifelong, avid collector of minerals, books, and mining memorabilia, especially from Franklin, NJ. His library ranks among the most extensive private libraries in the world dedicated to mining and mineralogy. Pronounced HOW-KITE.

results.aboutname: Named after Paul Hibon, a French prospector in Madagascar, who discovered the mineral in June 1953. He sent a parcel with some samples to Jean Behier for examination in the same year. Behier recognized it as a possible new mineral and gave it the working name "hibonite". He forwarded the sample to C. Guillemin, Labratoire de Minéralogie de la Sorbonne, in Paris, France to be further analyzed. It resulted in a description of the new mineral by Curien et al. (1956).

Högbom collaborated with Nobel Price winner, Svante Arrhenius. Högbom worked on the origin and consequences of atmospheric carbon, the deposition of limestone and its affect on the carbon dioxide budget, and research into the formation of continental ice sheets.

results.name: Hydroxylapatite
results.tlform: Concretions resembling chalcedony.
results.occurrence: Originally found in fracture fillings in an argillaceous schist (St. Girons, France).
results.otheroccurrence: Abundant in sedimentary phosphate beds. Occasionally found in Talc-schist; in diallage-serpentine rock. May be be found in late-stage phosphate mineralization in granite pegmatites,
results.colour: White, grey, yellow, green, violet, purple, red or brown
results.aboutname: Named hydro-apatite in 1856 by Augustin Alexis Damour from the ἀπατάω (apatao), to deceive as Apatite was often confused with other minerals (e.g. Beryl, Milarite), plus the "hydro-" prefix for the water-rich (as hydroxyl) nature of the mineral. Waldemar Schaller changed the name slightly to hydroxyl-apatite in 1912 and the one-word, hydroxylapatit, was introduced by Burri, Jakob, Parker, and Hugo Strunz in 1935. Additional names applied to this mineral include: pyroclasite, ornithite, monite, etc. Much "carbonate-apatite" is hydroxylapatite, including some dahllite, collophane, etc.
results.other: Soluble in HCl or in HNO3. Varieties containing CO3 may dissolve with slight effervescence.
results.morphology: Crystals short to long hexagonal prisms [0001], with <mi>{10_10}</mi> and <mi>{10_11}</mi> dominant; also thick tabular {0001}, frequently in the crystals of hydrothermal origin in pegmatites and veins, with <mi>{10_10}</mi>, relatively large {0001}, and often also <mi>{10_11}</mi> or low pyramids. Very sharp crystals are uncommon and terminations are frequently rounded. Massive, coarse granular to compact.
results.twinning: Rare contact twins on <mi>{11_21}</mi>. Twin plane <m>{10_13}</mi> rare. Also twinning reported on <mi>{10_10}</mi> and <mi>{11_23}.
results.commentdense: Density may be lower when earthy in texture.
results.commentcolor: Ideally white; other colors usually due to staining

results.name: Indialite

results.aboutname: Named in honor of Pavel Vladimirovitch Jeremejev (Павел Владимирович Еремеев) (9 March 1830 - 6 January 1899, St. Petersburg, Russian Empire), Russian mineralogist, engineer, and Professor at the St. Petersburg Academy of Sciences.  He collected the first specimens and suspected that they were a new mineral.
results.morphology: Crystals long prismatic, elongated [0001]. Terminations rounded, irregular, or indented at times and the prism faces modified by vicinal planes.

Newberry in  1980 in honor of Mr. John Leach Baum [March 15, 1916 New York, New York, USA - October 16, 2011 Hamburg, New Jersey, USA], graduate of Harvard University and student under Dr. Charles Palache. results.name: Lonsdaleite
results.tlform: Black cubes and cubo-octahedrons up to about 0.7 mm in size.
results.occurrence: Meteorite. Residue left from dissolving of the Canyon Diablo meteorite.
results.otheroccurrence: In meteorites and kimberlite.
results.aboutname: Named in honor of Dame Kathleen Lonsdale (nee Yardley) (28 January 1903, Newbridge, County Kildare, Ireland - 1 April 1971, London, England), crystallographer who established the structure of benzene by X-ray diffraction methods in 1929. She also worked on the synthesis of diamonds, and was a pioneer in the use of X-rays to study crystals.
results.morphology: Fine grained aggregates
results.type_specimen_store: Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA, 130245.
results.commenthard: Handbook of Mineralogy gives "3". "imperfections in natural Lonsdaleite reduce hardness, artificial material has tested harder than diamond (>10) , See Physical Review letters (2009). Wikipedia states “Lonsdaleite is simulated to be 58% harder than diamond on the <100> face and to resist indentation pressures of 152 GPa, whereas diamond would break at 97 GPa.[21] This is yet exceeded by IIa diamond's <111> tip hardness of 162 GPa.”

results.name: Lourenswalsite

results.name: Moissanite

results.industrial: Natural moissanite is too rare to be exploited, but synthetic silicon carbide is produdced as an abrasive, and synthetic moissanite crystals are grown to use as a gemstone and diamond simulant.
results.colour: Green, black, blue, colourless, green yellow, yellow
results.aboutname:
Named in 1905 after Ferdinand Frederick Henri Moissan (28 September 1852 – 20 February 1907), a French chemist who, after years of research of high-temperature methods and furnaces for the production of carbides and synthetic diamonds, discovered the natural occurrence in the Canyon Diablo meteorite.

Moissan was the first to isolate elemental fluorine and received the 1906 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for that.
results.other: Concentrated sulfuric, nitric, and hydrochloric acids do not decompose it at their boiling point.  Attacked by molten lead chromate.  Does not burn in oxygen at 1000 C.

results.name: Molybdenite
results.aboutname: Variations of the name molybdaena and molybdenite were used for lead ores by Dioscorides (50-70 CE), Pliny the Elder (79 CE), and Agricola (1556), but the modern use of molybdenite did not begin until Johan Gottschalk Wallerius wrote about molybdenite in Mineralogia, eller Mineralriket published in 1747. There was still a multiplicity of minerals receiving the same name, but modern molybdenite and graphite were the most common minerals given this name. The element molybdenum was discovered by Carl Wilhelm Scheele in 1778 and he provided molybdenite to Peter Jacob Hjelm who was able to isolate molybdenum in 1781. Scheele showed that molybdenite, in the modern sense, was soluble in acid, while graphite was not. From the Greek μόλυβδοζ meaning "lead", but a name having a new usage unlike that of former times.
results.morphology: Tabular crystals, flakes

results.name: Osumilite-(Mg)
results.tlform: Blue to brown transparent vitreous short prismatic or thick tabular hexagonal crystals up to 0.5 × 1 mm in size.

results.morphology:
Type material:
Common crystal faces are {100} and {001} with rare {101} and {110}.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: ε = colorless to ω = light blue.
results.ir:
Very similar to that of osumilite.

Main absorption bands (cm–1, s = strong, sh = shoulder):
1138s, 1000sh, 950s [stretching vibrations of (Si,Al)O4 tetrahedra], 770sh, 745, 717, 652, 541s (mixed vibrations of tetrahedral rings), 475, 440, 401s, 378s (combined modes with bending vibrations Si-O-Si and stretching vibrations of Mg octahedra).

For osumilite the wavenumber of the latter band is lower (367 cm–1) due to the predominance of Fe+2 over Mg in the octahedral site. The bands related to H-, B-, or C-bearing groups are absent in IR spectrum
results.type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4174/1.

Named by Nobuhide Murakami, Toshio Kato, Yasunori Miura, and Fumitoshi Hirowatari in 1976 in honor of Ken-ichi Sugi (杉健一) (15 May 1901, Kashiwazaki, Niigata Prefecture, Japan - 16 July 1948, Fukuoka, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan), petrologist at the Imperial University Kyushu, who first found the occurrence of the mineral with M. Kutsuna.

Sugilite is an example of a mineral name pronounced wrongly more often than correctly. Named after Japanese petrologist Dr. Kenichi Sugi, whose name is pronounced with a hard "g" (as in "geese"), whereas most English speakers mispronounce it with a soft "g" (as in "gene"). This wasn't much of an issue when sugilite was just an obscure ugly greenish-yellowish-brown rock-forming mineral from Japan, but when it was found in South Africa as large quantities of bright purple lapidary rock and thousands of people in the gem trade started talking about it, the bad pronunciation became entrenched (Alfredo Petrov 2014).

results.name: Svabite

results.aboutname: Named in 1891 by (Sten Anders) Hjalmar Sjögren in honor of Anton von Swab (Svab) [July 29, 1703 Fahlun, Sweden - January 28, 1768 Stockholm, Sweden], chemist, mineralogist, and Swedish mining official - Bergmästaregatan in Skåne and Kronoberg. Swab was a step-brother of Emmanuel Swedenborg. Swab made important discoveries. He refined zinc from calamine and later from blende and together with Axel Cronstedt developed a commercial process for refining zinc and in turn greatly aided the manufacture of brass in Sweden. Swab also discovered native antimony at Sala, Sweden. Weeks (1960) cited an obituary of Anton von Swab and Georg Brandt written by Carl von Linne: "The kingdom and our sciences have now lost in a single year two stars of the first magnitude, Brandt and Svab. The Bureau of Mines and the science of mining have lost their supporting pillars. Men such as these never spring up like mushrooms. So far as I know, Europe has none like them. ... A king can lose an army, but within a year have another ]ust as good. A king can lose a fleet and within two years have another rigged up, but a Brandt and a Svab cannot be gotten again during his entire reign"

(x, y, n < 1); the Mindat formula is a simplified version of the simplified crystallochemical formula from the abstract (Chukanov et al. 2024): (Na<sub>3.89–5.18</sub>K<sub>0.15–1.64</sub>Ca<sub>2.30–2.58</sub>(Al<sub>6</sub>Si<sub>6</sub>O<sub>24</sub>)(SO<sub>4</sub>,S<sub>5</sub><sup>2−</sup>,S<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2−x</sub> (Cl<sup>−</sup>,HS<sup>−</sup>)<sub>1+y</sub>·nH<sub>2</sub>O (x, y, n < 1); may bear trace S<sub>2</sub>·<sup>−</sup> and S<sub>3</sub>·<sup>−</sup> radicals' admixtures;
formerly given as (Na,Ca,K)<sub>8</sub>(Al<sub>6</sub>Si<sub>6</sub>O<sub>24</sub>)(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Cl.H<sub>2</sub>O

results.twinning: Polysynthetic twinning is a specific feature of tounkite. The boundaries of twin components, connected by a rotation of 180° around the [001] axis, run perpendicular to this axis, along the planes of the six-membered rings.  A large 10-layed cage formed at the border between twin components, connected by a rotation of 180° around the [001] axis, which may host the large S52− anion
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: O = colorless; E = yellow-green.

results.commentcolor:
The observed differences in the colors are associated with the different amounts of polysulfide groups contained in them. Both samples contain different amounts S52− anions, which are a yellow chromophore, and minor admixtures of the S3− radical anions, which are a very strong blue chromophore,  Sample 2 contains significant amounts of S4
molecules (a weak red chromophore) and Sample 3 contains S2− radical anions (a yellow chromophore). Thus, the blue color of Sample 2 is mainly related to the presence of S3− and S4, whereas the green color of Sample 3 is due to the combination of S3−, S2− and S52−.

results.name: Troilite
results.occurrence: meteorite
results.otheroccurrence: Troilite occurs in serpentine, in layered ultramafic intrusives, and in meteorites. Known terrestial occurrences of troilite are not common. Found in a great number of meteorites (also Lunar and Martian) and in planetary nebulae. Found in slags and also in pulverized coal particles after combustion. Based on observations by the Voyager spacecraft in 1979 and Galileo in 1996, troilite seems to be an important phase in the mineral composition of the model rock of Jupiter's Galilean satellites Ganymede and Callisto. Based on the observations of Viking-1 and Viking-2-XRF-soil analyses and Phobos-2 orbital γ-ray data, troilite is likely to be a common mineral in the Martian surface rocks.
results.colour: Gray brown, bronze brown (tarnished), yellow brown, light greyish brown, bronze
results.aboutname:
Named after Domenico Troili (1722–1792) who first noted the mineral in a meteorite that fell in 1766 at Albareto, Modena (Italy).

Troilite is the only Italian mineral whose type locality is actually a meteorite impact site. The Abbé Domenico Troili, of the Society of Jesus, is widely credited by those who study meteorites as having written the first description of the fall of a meteorite (“Ragionamento della caduta di un sasso”, published in Modena in 1766). Troili collected reports from many eyewitnesses, closely examined the stone and detected in it small grains of a brassy mineral he called “marchesita”, which was long assumed to be pyrite, FeS2. Only one century later the mineral was recognized to be stoichiometric iron sulphide, FeS. In honour of Troili, Gustav Rose named it troilite in 1862.

results.aboutname: Named after Anatolyi Vladimirovich Berezansky (Анатолий Владимирович Березанский) (b. 1948), who mapped the geology of remote areas of the Turkestan-Alai range, in Tajikistan.
results.other: Insoluble  in  water  or  1:1  HCl
results.uv: Bright bluish white fluorescence in short-wave ultraviolet light
results.type_specimen_store: Mining museum of the St. Petersburg Mining Institute, Russia and in the Ilmen Natural Reserve museum, Miass, Russia.

results.name: Blatonite
results.tlform: Very thin asbestiform aggegates; the bundles of needle-shaped subparallel fibers are up to 0.1 mm in width and 1 mm in length. Some crystals are fan-like and terminated.
results.occurrence: oxidized portions of a roll-front-type uranium deposit
results.aboutname: Named in 1998 by R. Vochten  and Michel Deliens in honor of Dr. Norbert Blaton [Zwalm, East-Flanders province, Belgium, May 25 1945-], crystallographer at the University of Leuven, Belgium, a specialist on the crystal structure of uranium minerals.
results.other: Soluble with effervescence in dilute mineral acids and in dilute organic acids such as acetic acid.
results.uv: Fluoresces strongly greenish yellow under 360 nm UV
results.type_specimen_store: Royal Belgian Institute of Natural Sciences, Brussels
results.commentdense: Measured in Clerici solution. Calculated value is based on ideal formula.
results.commentcrystal: Point Group: n.d.; Space Group: n.d

results.name: Charmarite-2H
results.description_short: The 2H polytype was originally described from Poudrette quarry (Demix quarry; Uni-Mix quarry; Desourdy quarry), Mont Saint-Hilaire, Rouville Co., Québec, Canada.
results.aboutname: Named for Charles (1917-2003) and Marcelle (1918-2003) Weber, amateur mineralogists of Guilford, Connecticut, USA, who contributed extensively to the knowledge of Mt. St.-Hilaire and also found the mineral.
results.other: Attacked by 1:1 HCl and HNO3 with effervescence, and dissolve in 1:1 H2SO4 with effervescence.
results.morphology: Tabular hexagonal crystals, commonly stacked along [0001] to form pagoda like aggregates. Also as thin mica-like plates, sometimes forming star-shaped aggregates. Stacked tabular crystals can show parallel-growth features along {0001}. The most common forms observed are {0001} and <mi>{10_10}</mi>.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc:
Weak pleochroism in pale-blue varieties. ω = colorless, ε = pale blue.
Strong pleochroism in the orange-brown varieties. ω = orange-brown, ε = very pale brown.

results.name: Dusmatovite
results.mindat_formula_note: IMA formula given for dusmatovite is actually close to the correct formula for darapiosite (but with 2K in the $b site rather than 2Na). However, this formula appears to be in error in several respects (both in the $b and $t2 site occupancies). The correct $t2 site Li-free (all Zn) and $b site (K+[]) end-member formula is given in Gagné & Hawthorne (2016).
results.tlform: Grains, in aggregates up to 4 x 5 cm.
results.occurrence: Boulder of pegmatite in a glacial moraine.
results.aboutname: For Vyacheslav Djuraevitch Dusmatov (1936-2004), Mineralogist and geologist who has done much work at the locality.
results.morphology: grains in aggregates
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: light blue (E), light violet (O)
results.type_specimen_store: Museum of the Ilmen State Preserve, Miass, Russia.

results.name: Erionite-Ca
results.tlform: Woolly white radial aggregates of fibers. The fibers reach 2 x 0.05 mm in size.
results.occurrence: In thoroughly weathered and altered olivine basalt and andesite.
results.aboutname: Named in 1898 by Arthur Starr Eakle from the Greek εριον meaning wool in allusion to the "wooly" appearance of the type material. Erionite was first found at the Durkee Fire Opal Mine, Swayze Creek, Durkee, Baker Co., Oregon (Tschernich, 1992). In modern nomenclature, the original erionite was erionite-Na, but potassium was nearly equal to sodium. Levinson Rule suffix added in allusion to Ca dominant exchangeable cations.
results.type_specimen_store: No designated type material.
results.commentcrystal: Cell parameters from Harada et al 1967 (type material).

results.name: Fluorcaphite
results.tlform: Subhedral prisms up to 5 mm long, and in aggregates up to 15 mm across.
results.occurrence: In miarolitic cavities in the central part of a hyperagpaitic pegmatite in ijolite-urtite.
results.aboutname: Named after its constituting elements of fluorine, calcium, and phosphorous
results.other: Readily soluble in 10% HCl or HNO3.
results.ir: Distinct absorption bands at 400, 573, 601, 953, 1000 (shoulder), 1039, 1090 (shoulder), and two weak bands at 3360 and 3490 cm-1, generally corresponding to spectra for the apatite family.
results.type_specimen_store: A. E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Moscow, Russia.

results.name: Gmelinite-Ca
results.aboutname: Named by David Brewster in 1825 in honor of the German mineralogist and chemist, Christian Gottlob Gmelin (1792-1860) of University of Tübingen, Germany. The suffix indicates the dominant extra-framework cation. In 1997, the name gmelinite (without suffix) was promoted from species to series and gmelinite-Ca was defined as one of several species.

results.name: Gmelinite-K
results.tlform: Granular and radial aggregates of columnar to acicular crystals up to 0.1 x 3 mm (Russia).
results.occurrence: Found in cavities within brecciated pegmatite (Russia).
results.aboutname: Named after the German mineralogist and chemist, Christian Gottlob Gmelin (1792-1860) of Tübingen, Germany.  The suffix indicates the dominant extra-framework cation.  In 1997, the name gmelinite (without suffix) was promoted from species to series and gmelinite-K was defined as one of several species.

results.name: Gmelinite-Na
results.otheroccurrence: In basalts and pegmatites.
results.colour: Colorless, white, reddish white, salmon-red, yellowish, greenish white
results.aboutname: Named by David Brewster in 1825 in honor of the mineralogist and professor of chemistry, Christian Gottlob Gmelin [October 12, 1792- May 13, 1860] of the University of Tübingen, Germany.  The suffix indicates the dominant extra-framework cation. In 1997, the name gmelinite (without suffix) was promoted from species to series and gmelinite-Na was defined as one of several species.
results.morphology: Pyramidal, tabular, rhombohedral

results.name: Zálesíite
results.tlform:
transparent hexagonal crystals, up to 100 µm long and 10 µm wide
powdery coatings, cross-fiber veinlets, and tufts of acicular crystals
results.aboutname: Named after the type locality, Zálesí uranium deposit, Zálesí, Javorník, Jeseník District, Olomouc Region, Czech Republic
results.other: slowly soluble in dilute HCl.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: O = pale yellow-green, E = pale green
results.type_specimen_store:
Natural History Museum, National Museum Prague
Museum of the Bohemian Paradise, in Turnov, Czech Republic

results.name: Phosphoellenbergerite
results.tlform: Blue, anhedral inclusions, up to 0.5 mm long, in <M>heneuite</M>.
results.occurrence: In lenses of Precambrian serpentine-magnesite rocks of the Tingelstadtjern deposit, Modum terrane, southern Norway.
results.aboutname: Named as the phosphate analogue of <M>ellenbergerite</M>.  The root name is for François Théodore Victor Ellenberger (5 May 1915, Lealui, Northern Rhodesia (now Zambia) - 11 January 2000, Bures-sur-Yvette, France), Professor of Structural Geology, University of the Sorbonne, Paris. In 1976 he created the French Committee of History of Geology (COFRHIGEO) and published 'Histoire de la Géologie' in two volumes (1988 and 1994).
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: E = blue, O = colorless.

results.name: Pimelite
results.description_short: Dark grass to forest-green masses of pimelite are found in colour-zoned pods (to 1 meter) with yellow-green nickeloan nontronite associated with red-brown hematite-stained nontronite and adjacent to bright white montmorillonite pods in a weathering pro...
results.aboutname:
Named by Dietrich Ludwig Gustav Karsten in 1800 for the Greek word for "fat", in allusion to the mineral's appearance. Pimelite was determined to be a smectite as early as 1938 [also American Mineralogist 51:279 [1966]. Later erroneously ascribed to nickel-rich talc (American Mineralogist 64:615 [1979]).  Both nickel-bearing talc, intermediate nickeloan nontronite, and nickel dominant smectite occur at the type locality. A re-validation research project has begun.

A significant literature exists verifying that pimelite is nickel-dominant smectite, although there are studies which misidentified the starting material as "pimelite" and reached erroneous conclusions. Often thought to be a colouring agent in chrysoprase, but probably rarely present in that material.
results.morphology: Fine-grained
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: Pale green colorless to light yellow green
results.commentcrystal: Expands to 17.35 A using glycol

results.name: Quintinite
results.tlform: Equant and prismatic crystals. Hexagonal tabular crystals on {0001}, commonly forming rosettes.
results.occurrence: Late-stage hydrothermal mineral in miarolitic cavities and in pegmatitic bodies within nepheline syenite (quintinite-3T). Vugs in dolomitic carbonatite (quintinite-2H).
results.aboutname: Named in 1997 by George Y. Chao and Robert A. Gault in honor of Quintin Wight [b. April 23, 1935 Canada], of Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, significant contributor to mineral studies at Mont Saint-Hilaire, and author of "The Complete Book of Micromounting" (1993).
results.other: Quintinite-2H is attacked slightly by 1:1 HCl, more strongly by 1:1 HNO3, and very strongly by 1:1 H2SO4, all with effervescence. Quintinite-3T is attacked slightly by 1:1 HCl, strongly by HNO3, and dissolves in 1:1 H2SO4.
results.morphology: As equant and prismatic crystals displaying the forms {0001} and an {hkil} trapezohedron with or without <mi>{10_10}</mi>. As hexagonal tabular crystals on {0001}, commonly forming rosettes.
results.type_specimen_store:
Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, numbers CMNMI 81546, CMNMI 47266 and CMNMI 81548 (quintinite-2H) and CMNMI 81549 (quintinite-3T).
Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Ontario, Canada, numbers M46768, M46769, M46770
(quintinite-2H) and M46777 (quintinite-3T).

results.name: Shibkovite
results.mindat_formula_note: Previously given as K(□,K,Na)<sub>2</sub>Zn<sub>3</sub>Ca<sub>2</sub>[Si<sub>12</sub>O<sub>30</sub>].
results.tlform: Occurs as white to colorless equant grains, to 0.5 mm, resembling quartz.
results.aboutname: Named after two prominent Russian geologists, Viktor Sergeevitch Shibkov (Виктор Сергеевич Шибков) (1926-1992) and Nikolai Viktorovitch Shibkov (Николай Викторович Шибков) (1951-1991), who both spent their professional lives working on the geology of Soviet Asia.
results.other: Insoluble in water and 1:1 HCl
results.uv: Bright red fluorescence in short-wave ultraviolet light
results.type_specimen_store: Museum of the Ilmensky National Park at Miass, Russia, and in the A. E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Moscow, Russia.

results.name: Stoppaniite
results.mindat_formula_note: The formula is simplified; the real formula is very complex (Della Ventura et al., 2000): (Fe,Al,Mg)<sub>4</sub>(Be<sub>6</sub>Si<sub>12</sub>O<sub>36</sub>)<sup>.</sup>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>(Na,◻).
results.tlform: Transparent, light-blue, hexagonal-prismatic euhedral crystals, up to 0.5 mm in length.
results.occurrence: Miarolitic cavities of a volcanic ejectum.
results.aboutname: Named after Francesco Saverio Stoppani (b. 1947), lawyer from Rome (Italy), collector of minerals and coauthor of "I minerali del Lazio (1982)".
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: Colorless to very light blue.
results.type_specimen_store:
Museum of Mineralogy, University of Rome, Italy, MMUR-29900/1.
Natural History Museum, Paris, France, 198.14.

results.name: Wallkilldellite-(Fe)
results.occurrence: oxidation zone of copper arsenide deposit
results.aboutname: The suffix, Fe, indicates the iron analog of wallkilldellite
results.other: Soluble in HCl.
results.morphology: spherules, to 0.1 mm, consisting of extremely thin radiating plates,
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: O = brown; E = pale brown-yellow.
results.type_specimen_store: Muséum d’Histoire naturelle de Genève in Geneva, Switzerland.
results.commentluster: Vitreous on cleavage surfaces; slightly resinous on fracture surfaces.
results.commentcrystal: <mi>Point Group: 6/m 2/m 2/m, _6m2, or 6mm. ;  Space Group: P63/mmc, P_62c, or P63mc</mi>

results.name: Genèvéite
results.description_short:
Probably identical to Theisite.

Originally described from Tyrol, Austria.
Never submitted to the IMA, but name published nonetheless.
results.tlform: Botryoidal aggregates (to 0.3mm diam.) of thin hexagonal plates.
results.aboutname: Named after the city of Genève.
results.type_specimen_store: Museum de Genèvé

results.name: Malinkoite
results.tlform: Rosette-like intergrowths of wedge-shaped crystals and spherulites (up to 3 mm across).
results.occurrence: Hyperagpaitic pegmatite intruded into foyaite.
results.otheroccurrence: Hyperagpaitic pegmatite intruded in foyaite
results.aboutname: Named by A.P. Khomyakov, G.N. Nechelyustov, E.V. Sokolova, and F.C. Hawthorne in 2000 in honor of Svetlana Vyacheslavovna Malinko (Светлана Вячеславовна Малинко) (14 June 1927 - 2002), Russian mineralogist at the Institute of Mineral Resources, Moscow, Russia. She specializes in minerals containing boron and has discovered several new ones.
results.type_specimen_store: A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Moscow, Russia.

results.name: Micheelsenite
results.tlform: As acicular to fibrous crystals in loosely packed aggregates to 3mm in diameter and in bundles of hair-like matted fibers (Mont Saint Hilaire). As white, irregular bundles or partly fan-shaped aggregates of fibrous, acicular crystals (Nanna pegmatite).
results.occurrence: In pegmatites (in socalled "silicate cavities"), seams in hornfels and marble xenoliths at the Poudrette quarry, Mont Saint Hilaire, Quebec, Canada and in the Nanna pegmatite, Greenland.
results.aboutname: Named by A.M. McDonald, O.V. Petersen, R.A. Gault, O. Johnsen, G. Niedrmayr, F. Brandstätter, and G. Giester, G. in 2001 in honor of Harry Ingvar Micheelsen (1931 - 2020) Danish mineralogist, former Professor of Mineralogy, University of Copenhagen. His specialty was mineralogy of alkaline rocks and he discovered the Nanna pegmatite (one of the type localities).
results.other: Effervesces strongly in dilute HCl.
results.morphology: Acicular, fibrous crystals, with typical hexagonal cross-sections. Striated along [001], terminated by {001}. In loosely packed spherical,fan-shaped or randomly matted aggregates.
results.type_specimen_store: Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada (CMNMC 83049/50) and in the Geological Museum, University of Copenhagen, Denmark

results.name: Megakalsilite
results.tlform: irregularly shaped grain 2 -3 mm across,
results.occurrence: Hyperagpaitic pegmatite in ijolite–urtite, near their contact with apatite–nepheline rocks.
results.aboutname: Named in allusion to the size of the Z value since it shares the same chemical formula with kalsilite, but its unit cell is 12 times larger.
results.type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum, catalogue #2624/1, Russian Academy of Sciences, in Moscow, Russia.

results.name: Magnesiohögbomite-2N2S
results.occurrence: Rock-making mineral in iron ores.
results.cleavage: 'Not well marked, but apparently both basal and rhombohedral'
results.aboutname: Originally described as högbomite, after Arvid Gustav Högbom (11 January 1857, Vännäs, Västerbotten, Sweden - 19 January 1940, Uppsala, Sweden)), University of Uppsala, Sweden. Renamed according to the new högbomite group nomenclature (Armbruster 2002).
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: O = dark but still yellowish brown; E = bright yellow brown.
results.type_specimen_store: No designated type specimen.
results.commentcolor: Brown in thin sections.
results.ima_history: Renamed as magnesiohögbomite-2N2S by IMA 2001 (special procedure, IMA Case 01–A).

results.name: Mazzite-Na
results.tlform: White, very thin, flexible fibers up to 2 mm in length, commonly filling small cavities as satiny mats.
results.occurrence: In basalt.
results.aboutname:
Named for its relationship to <m>mazzite-Mg</m>, with a suffix indicating the incorporation of sodium rather than magnesium.

The root name is for Fiorenzo Mazzi (1924 Forence, Italy - 25 September 2017, Pavia, Italy), Professor of Mineralogy at the University of Pavia, Italy. He made significant contributions to the understanding of zeolite structure.
results.type_specimen_store: n.d.

results.name: Fluorcalciobritholite
results.tlform: Grains and minute elongated crystals
results.otheroccurrence: In veinlets in an alkaline complex
results.aboutname: The name follows convention and denotes its dominant fluorine and calcium content and its relationship to other britholite group minerals.
results.morphology: long-prismatic hexagonal crystals up to 0.5 x 10 mm
results.type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, no. 3420/1.

results.name: Metathénardite
results.tlform: Hexagonal tabular, lamellar, or dipyramidal crystals (forms: {001}, {100}, {102}, and {201}) up to 3 mm combined in crusts up to several hundred cm2 in area.
results.occurrence: Volcanic fumaroles.
results.colour: Colorless, white, light-blue, greenish, yellowish, grayish or brownish,
results.aboutname: Originally reported by Lacroix (1905) as a hypothetical mineral from <l id='127286'>Mt. Pelée, Martinique, Lesser Antilles, French West Indies</l>. Named for being a dimorph of thénardite formed at high temperatures and unstable at room temperature. Approved by IMA in 2016 on submitted material from <l id='259833'>Glavnaya Tenoritovaya fumarole, Tolbachik volcano, Kamchatka, Russia</l>.
results.other: Dissolves in H2O at room temperature.
results.morphology: Hexagonal tabular to lamellar. Pinacoid {001} (usually the major form), with the hexagonal prism {100}, the hexagonal dipyramid {102} and narrow faces of the hexagonal dipyramid {201}.
results.type_specimen_store: Collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia (registration number 4771/1).

results.name: Demartinite
results.tlform: Colorless hexagonal pyramidal crystals up to 0.3 mm across.
results.occurrence: From a fumarole, on a fragment of altered pyroclastic breccia.
results.aboutname: After Francesco Demartin (born 1953), professor of General and Inorganic Chemistry and Stechiometry at the University of Milan, Italy. He has made significant contributions to the chemistry of metallic clusters in organometallic compounds and to the crystal structure of Alpine rare-earth minerals and uranium minerals.
results.other: Not hygroscopic.
results.morphology: Hexagonal pyramidal crystals. The observed forms are the pedion {001} and the hexagonal pyramid {112}.
results.type_specimen_store: State University of Milan, Italy, number 2006-1.

results.name: Quintinite-2H
results.description_short: The 2H polytype was originally described from Jacupiranga alkaline complex, Cajati, São Paulo, Brazil.
results.aboutname: Named in 1997 by George Y. Chao and Robert A. Gault in honor of Quintin Wight [b. April 23, 1935 Canada], of Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, significant contributor to mineral studies at Mont Saint-Hilaire, and author of "The Complete Book of Micromounting" (1993). The 3T polytype was first found at Mont Saint-Hilaire.
results.other: Attacked slightly by 1:1 HCl, more strongly by 1:1 HNO3, and very strongly by 1:1 H2SO4, all with effervescence.
results.morphology: As equant and prismatic crystals displaying the forms {0001} and an {hkil} trapezohedron with or without <mi>{10_10}</mi>.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: ω = yellow, ε = lighter yellow.

results.name: Hydroxylborite
results.tlform: Hexagonal prisms without end faces, about 1-1.5 x 0.1-0.2 mm in size. Commonly as radial and fan-like aggregate.
results.occurrence: Mineralized skarn, calciphyre, and marble. Clinohumite calciphyre.
results.aboutname: In allusion to its composition, being the HYDROXYL dominant member of the series with fluoBORITE.
results.other: Dissolves in concentrated H2SO4, readily reacts with quinalizarin, and remains insoluble in water and dilute HCl.
results.morphology: Crystals prismatic with dominant <mi>{10_10}</mi> and without distinct terminal faces; also occurs as radial aggregates.
results.type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Moscow (#91968), and the Geology Museum of the All-Russian Scientific Research Institute of Mineral Resources (#M-1663).

results.name: Kyanoxalite
results.tlform: Colorless to pale bluish anhedral, isometric to prismatic grains to 2mm.
results.occurrence: Typically in tiny veinlets between nepheline grains or as replacement rims surrounding sodalite-nosean masses in matrix.
results.colour: Pale bluish, bright blue, greenish-blue, grayish-blue or colorless
results.aboutname: Name reflects the mineral's blue color and the presence of oxalate
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: E = colourless, O = light blue
results.type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration 3735/1.

results.name: Balliranoite
results.tlform: Crystals up to 1x1x2 mm in cavities and as anhedral grains up to 1 cm in the groundmass.
results.occurrence: A product of metasomatic interaction between alkaline magma and limestone.
results.aboutname: Named in honor of Professor Paolo Ballirano (b. 1964), Professor of Crystallography, Department of Earth Sciences, University of Rome "La Sapienza", for his contributions to the crystal chemistry of cancrinite group minerals.
results.morphology: The prismatic faces, probably <mi>{10_10}</mi>, have striations parallel to [0001].
results.type_specimen_store: A. E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia (catalog no. 3756/1).

results.name: Berborite-2H
results.description_short: Original described from Saga 1 Quarry, Mørje, Porsgrunn, Telemark, Norway
results.tlform: White aggregate of 10-15 mm long 0.1 mm thick prisms
results.occurrence: Nepheline-syenite pegmatite
results.commentcolor: crystals may have transparent cores and milky white rims

results.name: Guidottiite
results.tlform: Columnar, with grains, ranging in size up to ~3 mm; poorly adhered to each other.
results.occurrence: Stratiform manganese deposit.
results.aboutname: Named in honour of Charles V. Guidotti (19 September 1935, Somerville, Massachusetts, USA - 19 May 2005, Boston, Massachusetts, USA), professor at the University of California, Davis (1962–1969), the University of Wisconsin–Madison (1969–1981), and the University of Maine (1981–2005), for his many contributions to phyllosilicate mineralogy. He also made important contributions to the petrologic studies of metamorphic rocks in the northern Appalachian Mountains of Maine.
results.type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History (Smithsonian Institution), Washington, D.C., USA, NMNH 174879.
results.commentluster: Vitreous in bulk, silky under magnification
results.commentdense: Measured on bulk sample with impurities. Calculated value is based on sets of microprobe analyses.

results.name: Depmeierite
results.tlform: Equant grains up to 1 cm in size.
results.occurrence: In a 1.5 cm thick hydrothermal veinlet cutting the peralkaline rocks of a differentiated foyaite–urtite–lujavrite complex.
results.aboutname: Named in 2010 by Igor V. Pekov, L. V. Olysych, N. V. Chukanov, K. V. Van, and D. Yury Pushcharovsky in honor of German crystallographer and mineralogist Wulf Helmut Heinz Depmeier [b.1944], Professor of Mineralogy and Crystallography at Christian-Albrechts University in Kiel. He is a well known specialist in crystal chemistry of the sodalite-cancrinite family of minerals and structurally related synthetic compounds.
results.type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia (registration no. 3882/1).
results.commentcolor: Coarse grains have a bluish tint

results.name: Cordylite-(La)
results.mindat_formula_note:
Formula with Z=1 more clear show composition peculiarities of the mineral with developed heterovalent isomorphism Na + REE = Ca + Sr.
(NaCa)Ba<sub>2</sub>((La,Ce)<sub>3</sub>Sr)(CO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>8</sub>F<sub>2</sub>
results.tlform: Colorless to yellow, irregularly-shaped, tabular, or short-prismatic hexagonal crystals up to about 3 mm across.
results.occurrence: Carbonatite veins in fenites.
results.aboutname: Named as the La-analogue of cordylite-(Ce).
results.morphology: Irregularly-shaped, tabular, or short-prismatic hexagonal crystals. Froms observed are <mi>{10_10}</mi> and {0001}.
results.type_specimen_store:
Mineral Science Department, Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, Los Angeles, USA (63360).
A.E. Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia (4028/1, 4029/1).

results.name: Krasheninnikovite
results.tlform: Long-prismatic to acicular crystals up to 3 mm long and up to 20 μm thick. The crystals are combined in sheaf-like, radiating or open-work matted aggregates forming nests up to several cm3 or crusts.
results.occurrence: Found in sublimates of an active fumarole
results.aboutname: Named in 2011 by I.V. Pekov et al. in honor of Stepan Petrovich Krasheninnikov (Степа́н Петро́вич Крашени́нников) (11 November 1711, Moscow, Russia - 8 March 1755, Saint Petersburg, Russia), one of first scientists to research the Kamchatka Peninsula. He was a naturalist, botanist, and geographer. The Krasheninnikov Volcano on Kamchatka is also named in his honor.
results.morphology: Long-prismatic to acicular crystals up to 3 mm long and up to 20 μm thick.
results.type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow,Russia, registration number 4112/1
results.commentcolor: Colorless in individuals and white in aggregates

results.name: Whitecapsite
results.occurrence: Found in the oxidation zone of the White Caps gold deposit.
results.aboutname: Named for the type locality, White Caps mine, Nye Co., Nevada
results.morphology: Hexagonal prismatic crystals terminated with bipyramidal faces (forms: {110} and {111})
results.ir: confirms the presence of H<sup>+</sup>·nH<sub>2</sub>O complex cations and absence of OH groups (also confirmed by Raman spectroscopy)
results.type_specimen_store: Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia

results.name: Minohlite
results.mindat_formula_note: Cu:Zn is somewhat variable.
results.tlform: Rosette aggregates up to 100 μm in diameter, composed of hexagonal platy crystals up to 50 μm in diameter and 10 μm in thickness.
results.occurrence: A secondary mineral in the oxidation zone of a Zn-Cu deposit in shale.
results.aboutname: Named after Minoh City, where it was discovered.
results.other: Easily soluble in dilute hydrochloric acid.
results.type_specimen_store: Type material has been deposited in the collections of the National Museum of Nature and Science, Japan, catalogue numbers NSMM43670 and NSM-M43671, and the Kyoto University Museum, Japan, catalogue number KUM-M00001.
results.commentcrystal: Hexagonal (trigonal); space group uncertain (possibly:  P6, P-6, P6/m, P622,  P6mm, P-62m or P6/mmm (P3, P-3, P321,  P3m1, P-3m1, P312, P31m or P-31m)).

results.name: Ferroindialite
results.tlform: Short prismatic or thick tabular hexagonal crystals up to 1.5 mm in size
results.occurrence: In a burnt xenolith of pelitic rock among alkaline basalts.
results.colour: Brownish-violet to gray with violet-blue tint
results.aboutname: For being the iron analogue of <m>indialite</m>.
results.other: IR spectrum shows the absence of H2O or ОН groups
results.morphology: Short prismatic or thick tabular hexagonal crystals.
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: X = colorless, Z = pale violet.
results.type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4400/1

results.name: Genplesite
results.tlform: Equant, short prismatic or thick tabular hexagonal crystals up to 0.5 mm and crystal clusters up to 0.6 x 1.2 mm.
results.occurrence: found in cavities in massive chalcopyrite
results.aboutname: Genplesite is named in honour of Gennadiy N. Plesin (b. 1963), a mine surveyor at the Oktyabr'sky mine and an amateur mineralogist who found the mineral.
results.type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4566/1

results.name: Alexkhomyakovite
results.tlform: Equant grains up to 0.2 mm, veinlets up to 3 cm long and up to 1 mm thick and fine-grained aggregates replacing delhayelite
results.occurrence: peralkaline pegmatite
results.aboutname: Named in honour of Alexander Petrovich Khomyakov (Александр Петрович Хомяков) (2 April 1933, Moscow, Russia – 12 October 2012, Moscow, Russia), mineralogist and Director of the Institute of Mineralogy, Geochemistry and Crystal Chemistry of Rare Elements.  He described more than 100 new minerals.  The minerals <m>khomyakovite</m> and <m>manganokhomyakovite</m> are also named for him.
results.type_specimen_store: Type material is deposited in the collections of the Fersman Mineralogical Museum, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russia, registration number 4696/1

results.name: Gajardoite
results.tlform: Hexagonal plates
results.aboutname: Named in honor of Aníbal Gajardo Cubillos (b. 1945), Chilean geologist. He has more than 200 publications, especially on the non-metallic mineral deposits of Chile. He has held several leadership positions in SERNAGEOMIN, Chile’s National Geology and Mining Service, and was professor in the Department of Geology, University of Chile from 1979 to 2009. He was also President of the Association of Geologists of Chile.  Pronounced /ga:′ha:r dOu ait/.
results.other: Very slowly soluble in water; slowly soluble in dilute HCl (room temperature).
results.morphology: Hexagonal plates, up to ca. 100 x 5 μm, forming subparallel rosette-like intergrowths
results.type_specimen_store: Co-type material is deposited in the mineralogical collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA, catalogue numbers 65585, 65586 and 65587

results.name: Russoite
results.tlform: Hexagonal plates up to about 300μm in diameter and 15μm thick, in rosette-like intergrowths.
results.occurrence: Fumarole
results.aboutname: Named in honor of Massimo Russo (b. 16 February 1960, Naples, Italy) geologist and researcher at the "Osservatorio Vesuviano", National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology in Naples.  He has written several books and articles on Italian volcanoes.
results.morphology: Hexagonal plates flattened on {001} and bounded by {100}.
results.type_specimen_store: Reference Collection of the DCSSI, Università degli Studi di Milano, catalogue number 2015-01.
results.commenthard: Crystals too small to measure hardness
results.commentdense: Measured by flotation in diiodomethane/benzene solution, calculated using empirical formula
results.commentcrystal: Space group may be incorrect - the synthetic compound has space group P6/mmm (Wrześniewska et al., 2023).

results.name: Currierite
results.tlform: Hexagonal prisms, needles and hair-like fibres up to about 200 μm long, in sprays
results.occurrence: Secondary alteration phase
results.aboutname: The mineral is named in honour of Mr. Rock Henry Currier (Evanston, Illinois, August 25, 1940 - September 25, 2015), mindat.org manager, mineral dealer, collector, author and lecturer.
results.other: The mineral is slowly soluble in dilute HCl at room temperature.
results.morphology: Hexagonal prisms, needles and hair-like fibres up to about 200 μm long, in sprays. Forms observed: {100} and {001}.
results.type_specimen_store: Mineralogical collections of the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, 900 Exposition Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA 90007, USA (catalogue numbers 66266 for holotype, and 64057 and 64080 for cotype)
results.commentcrystal: The chain in the structure of currierite is identical to that in kaatialaite and a geometrical isomer of that in ferrinatrite.

results.name: UM1993-06-F:CaNaREEY

Chemically resembles gagarinite-(Y). Indeed, inferred to be isostructural with this species and related to it as described by a substitution: NaCa(Y,REE)F6-Na1.5(Y,REE)1.5F6.
